original_solution_mapping.L1: Each dress takes 4 square meters of fabric to make, so the number of dresses she can make will be 56/4 = <<56/4=14>>14 dresses.
original_solution_mapping.L2: Each dress takes 3 hours to make, thus she will have to work 14 dresses x 3 hours/dress = <<14*3=42>>42 hours.

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 782.
    Returns: the total number of hours Melissa has to work.
    """
    # L1
    total_fabric = 56 # 56 square meters of fabric
    fabric_per_dress = 4 # each dress takes 4 square meters of fabric
    num_dresses = total_fabric / fabric_per_dress

    # L2
    hours_per_dress = 3 # 3 hours to make
    total_work_hours = num_dresses * hours_per_dress

    # FA
    answer = total_work_hours
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: Each dress takes {fabric_per_dress} square meters of fabric to make, so the number of dresses she can make will be {total_fabric}/{fabric_per_dress} = <<{total_fabric}/{fabric_per_dress}={num_dresses}>>{num_dresses} dresses.

Each dress takes {hours_per_dress} hours to make, thus she will have to work {num_dresses} dresses x {hours_per_dress} hours/dress = <<{num_dresses}*{hours_per_dress}={total_work_hours}>>{total_work_hours} hours.

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: Each dress takes 56 square meters of fabric to make, so the number of dresses she can make will be 56/56 = <<56/56=1>>1 dresses.
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: Each dress takes 3 hours to make, thus she will have to work 1 dresses x 3 hours/dress = <<1*3=3>>3 hours.

explanation: Input misrepresentation. The value for 'total_fabric' (56) was used instead of 'fabric_per_dress' (4).
